manual:
I. Basic Experiment Information
1. Experiment Title: Yersinia enterocolitica Detection (Colorimetric Method)
2. Subject: Medicine & Health - Microbiology (Health-Related)
3. Experiment Objective: To detect the presence of Yersinia enterocolitica in a sample using a colorimetric reagent based on the enzymatic activity of the bacterium; understand the visual cue of color change that indicates a positive detection and the underlying biochemical principle.

II. Experimental Equipment
Test tubes (15×150 mm), micropipette and sterile tips, colorimetric reagent specific to Yersinia enterocolitica (substrate producing color in presence of bacterial enzyme), sterile sample diluent, water bath/incubator set to 37°C, rack for tubes, gloves, lab coat, goggles.

III. Experimental Procedure
Preparation Stage: Wear protective equipment (gloves, coat, goggles). Label two test tubes: Sample and Control. 
Sample Addition: Using a micropipette, transfer a measured volume (e.g., 1 mL) of the suspected sample into the Sample tube. Add the same volume of sterile diluent to the Control tube.
Reagent Addition: Add equal drops of the colorimetric reagent to each tube using sterile technique. Gently flick or mix the tubes to ensure uniform mixing.
Incubation: Place both tubes into a water bath or incubator at 37°C for 30 minutes (or shortened duration for demonstration).
Observation: Remove tubes and visually compare color changes: the sample tube may change color depending on bacterial enzymatic activity.
Termination: Record observations, dispose of biological waste per lab regulations, and clean equipment.

IV. Observation of Experimental Phenomena
1. Initial State: Both tubes contain pale yellow transparent reagent solution with similar appearance.
2. During Reaction: The sample tube slowly exhibits color enhancement, turning orange-red due to enzymatic conversion of the substrate. The control tube remains pale yellow.
3. End of Reaction: The difference in color intensity between sample and control becomes distinct; bright red indicates presence of Yersinia enterocolitica, no color change means absence.

V. Summary of Experimental Principles
This experiment applies the principle that Yersinia enterocolitica produces specific enzymes capable of catalyzing a chromogenic substrate. In the colorimetric method, a noncolored substrate reacts enzymatically to yield a colored product when bacterial enzymes are present. Thus, color change in the reagent indicates enzymatic activity and presence of Yersinia enterocolitica.
1. Core Principle: Enzyme-mediated substrate color conversion reflects microbial presence.
2. Analytical Logic: Comparison between control and test ensures specificity—only bacterial enzyme activity causes visible change.
3. Application: Colorimetric assays are safe, rapid, and suitable for preliminary pathogen screening.

VI. Experimental Precautions
1. Maintain sterile conditions to avoid contamination.
2. Do not inhale near open test tubes; use gloves and goggles always.
3. Ensure temperature stability during incubation for enzymatic reaction accuracy.
4. Observe color precisely under good illumination and record within 5 minutes post incubation.
5. Dispose of biological and chemical waste in designated containers following biosafety protocols.
